page.title: 08Houses.
page.content: Beckington affords many fine listed buildings some dating back to the twelfth century connected with the church and others connected with the wool trade. Bechington Abbey was built in 1169 as a Hospice and is now divided into two residences. One part called The Grange is now a cookery school. Abbey House in Goose St. was used by pilgrims and there is a row of alms houses nearby. Beckington has associations with Henry VIII and his wives. Seymour's Court is where Jane Seymour lived. The Wool Hall is now used as a recording studio for Tears for Fears and other pop groups. Many of the weavers cottages still remain. There are two small privately owned estates, two council estates and old peoples flats and bungalows.
